data.Sentence_cn: 课文37  衰老过程
data.Sentence: --- Lesson 37 The process of ageing

data.Sentence_cn: 随着年龄的增长，我们对自己最不愉快的发现是什么?
data.Sentence: What is one of the most unpleasant discoveries we make about ourselves as we get older?

data.Sentence_cn: 人体在12岁时是生命力最旺盛的时期。
data.Sentence: At the age of twelve years, the human body is at its most vigorous.

data.Sentence_cn: 虽然这个时期人的身材、体力和智力还有待发展和完善，但在这个年龄死亡的可能性最小。
data.Sentence: It has yet to reach its full size and strength, and its owner his or her full intelligence: but at this age the likelihood of death is least.

data.Sentence_cn: 再早一些，我们是幼儿和小孩子，身体较脆弱；
data.Sentence: Earlier, we were infants and young children, and consequently more vulnerable;

data.Sentence_cn: 再迟一些，我们就要经历生命力和抵抗力逐步衰退的过程。
data.Sentence: later, we shall undergo a progressive loss of our vigour and resistance which, though imperceptible at first

data.Sentence_cn: 虽然这个过程起初难以觉察，
data.Sentence: will finally become so steep that we can live no longer,

data.Sentence_cn: 但最终会急转直下，不管我们怎样精心照料我们自己，不管社会和医生怎样对我们进行精心照顾，我们也无法再活下去了。
data.Sentence: however well we look after ourselves, and however well society, and our doctors, look after us.

data.Sentence_cn: 生命力随着时间的流失而衰退叫做衰老。
data.Sentence: This decline in vigour with the passing of time is called ageing.

data.Sentence_cn: 人类发现的最不愉快的一个事实是：人必然会衰老。既使我们能避开战争、
data.Sentence: It is one of the most unpleasant discoveries which we all make that we must decline in this way, that if we escape wars,

data.Sentence_cn: 意外的事故和各种疾病，我们最终也会“老死”；衰老的速度在人与人之间相差甚微，
data.Sentence: accidents and diseases we shall eventually 'die of old age', and that this happens at a rate which differs little from person to person,

data.Sentence_cn: 我们最可能死亡的年龄在65至80岁之间，
data.Sentence: so that there are heavy odds in favour of our dying between the ages of 65 and 80.

data.Sentence_cn: 有些人会死得早一些，少数人寿命会长一些 -- 活到八十几岁或九十几岁，
data.Sentence: Some of us will die sooner, a few will live longer -- on into a ninth or tenth decade.

data.Sentence_cn: 但这种可能性很小。
data.Sentence: But the chances are against it,

data.Sentence_cn: 不管我们多么幸运，多么健壮，我们所希望的长寿实际上是有限度的。
data.Sentence: and there is a virtual limit on how long we can hope to remain alive, however lucky and robust we are.

data.Sentence_cn: 衰老的过程，不经提起，正常人容易忘记；一经提醒，才会记起。
data.Sentence: Normal people tend to forget this process unless and until they are reminded of it.

data.Sentence_cn: 我们对人总是要衰老的现象并不陌生，多年来就已认识到。生命随着时间流失而丧失活力，
data.Sentence: We are so familiar with the fact that man ages, that people have for years assumed that the process of losing vigour with time,

data.Sentence_cn: 人随着年龄的增长而接近死亡，这是不言而喻的，
data.Sentence: of becoming more likely to die the older we get, was something self-evident

data.Sentence_cn: 就像一壶热水迟早会凉不来，一双鞋渐渐会磨破一样。
data.Sentence: like the cooling of a hot kettle or the wearing-out of a pair of shoes.

data.Sentence_cn: 人们不但认识到所有的动物，
data.Sentence: They have also assumed that all animals,

data.Sentence_cn: 大概也认识到所有的有机物。如树木，甚至宇宙本身，从事物的本质上来说都会“磨损掉”。
data.Sentence: and probably other organisms such as trees, or even the universe itself, must in the nature of things 'wear out'.

data.Sentence_cn: 我们通常看到的大多数动物，即使能让它们活得足够长久的话，
data.Sentence: Most animals we commonly observe do in fact age as we do,

data.Sentence_cn: 也会像我们一样衰老的。
data.Sentence: if given the chance to live long enough;

data.Sentence_cn: 像上紧发条的手表那样的机械装置，或太阳，
data.Sentence: and mechanical systems like a wound watch, or the sun,

data.Sentence_cn: 也都会消耗完其能量（整个宇宙否如此，目前沿有争论）。
data.Sentence: do in fact run out of energy in accordance with the second law of thermodynamics (whether the whole universe does so is a moot point at present).

data.Sentence_cn: 不过，这些衰老的情况同人并不相似。
data.Sentence: But these are not analogous to what happens when man ages.

data.Sentence_cn: 手表停了依然是只手表，还可以重上好发条。
data.Sentence: A run-down watch is still a watch and can be rewound.

data.Sentence_cn: 然而一只老掉牙的手表，磨损太厉害，老得一点儿不准了，最终不值得修理了。
data.Sentence: An old watch, by contrast, becomes so worn and unreliable that it eventually is not worth mending.

data.Sentence_cn: 但是，手表决不会自行修理，它不是由有生命的部件组成，而是由金属组成，而金属可以随着磨擦而磨损殆尽。
data.Sentence: But a watch could never repair itself -- it does not consist of living parts, only of metal, which wears away by friction.

data.Sentence_cn: 而我们人，在一定时间内是可以自行修复的，除了暴病死或意外事故外，至少足以克服一切疾病和事故。
data.Sentence: We could, at one time, repair ourselves -- well enough, at least, to overcome all but the most instantly fatal illnesses and accidents.

data.Sentence_cn: 在12岁至80岁之间，我们逐渐丧失这种能力。
data.Sentence: Between twelve and eighty years we gradually lose this power;

data.Sentence_cn: 能使我们在12岁时病倒的疾病，到了80岁可能会使我们一厥不振而进入坟墓。
data.Sentence: an illness which at 12 would knock us over, at 80 can knock us out, and into our grave.

data.Sentence_cn: 假如我们能保持12岁时的旺盛生命力，
data.Sentence: If we could stay as vigorous as we are at twelve,

data.Sentence_cn: 那么我们当中的一半人过700年才会死去，剩下的一半人再过700年，才会又减少一半。
data.Sentence: it would take about 700 years for half of us to die, and another 700 for the survivors to be reduced by half again.
